descriptions: Our group helped in planning for, and developed software tools for the repository described here

In the “DAS-month” repository mentioned above, ETH contributed 4 distinct datasets to the project. Aside from that publication, the additional 7 publications mentioned below each include links to publicly accessible datasets and codes. They are available through different platforms (e.g., github, zenodo, ETH Library, our group website, etc.) as we experimented with different sharing methods and workflows. Our group software and models are available at https://cos.ethz.ch/software.html and https://cos.ethz.ch/models.html . These include some DAS related projects, but also other topics.
collaborative datasets from the DAS Month project connected us with 24 other universities
The following videos were produced in the last year and relate to open datasets relating to this ORD project
Software to read, write and visualize DAS data is developed publicly here
Each of the 8 publications listed below include some amount of data and corresponding code for analyses, all shared openly. Many build on the unified software framework developed on github.

Along with the software mentioned above, we outline practices for documentation and workflows for new projects. Along with the software on Github, Jupyter notebooks describe how data can be cleanly read, written and visualized.
presentations relate to works in progress, for which datasets will be openly shared and will use the software and metadata standards developed from this ORD project
standardization of the ORD and FAIR practices will benefit all

We joined an already planned workshop on sharing seismic data across governmental borders, the “EPOS/EMSC Seismology Workshop and GFZ International Training Course” in Podgorica, Montenegro. We were invited to help lead discussions on upcoming technologies and best practices. The section was titled: “On the varied uses of Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS), and future challenges in data management.”

We joined an already planned workshop on sharing seismic data across governmental borders, the “EPOS/EMSC Seismology Workshop and GFZ International Training Course” in Podgorica, Montenegro. We were invited to help lead discussions on upcoming technologies and best practices. The section was titled: “On the varied uses of Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS), and future challenges in data management.”
Andreas Wuestefeld, Zack J. Spica, et. al (2023); The Global DAS Month of February 2023. Seismological Research Letters 2023
Accepted, in Press: Bowden, D. C., Bozdag, E., Shaikhsulaimann A., Fichtner, A., Konca, O; Telecommunications Fibers Map Earthquake Hazards in Istanbul. EOS, American Geophysical Union

Andreas Fichtner, Coen Hofstede, Brian L. N. Kennett, Niels F. Nymand, Mikkel L. Lauritzen, Dimitri Zigone, Olaf Eisen (2023); Fiber‐Optic Airplane Seismology on the Northeast Greenland Ice Stream. The Seismic Record 3 (2): 125–133

Andreas Fichtner, Coen Hofstede, Lars Gebraad, Andrea Zunino, Dimitri Zigone, Olaf Eisen (2023), Borehole fibre-optic seismology inside the Northeast Greenland Ice Stream, Geophysical Journal International, Volume 235, Issue 3, Pages 2430–2441

Jörg Rychen, Patrick Paitz, Pascal Edme, Krystyna Smolinski, Joeri Brackenhoff, and Andreas Fichtner (2023); Test experiments with distributed acoustic sensing and hydrophone arrays for locating underwater sound. arXiv preprint arXiv:2306.04276
Linking Distributed and Integrated Fiber Optic Sensing, Geophysical Research Letters
Subglacial volcano monitoring with fibre-optic sensing: Grímsvötn, Iceland, Volcanica
Long-range fiber-optic earthquake sensing by active phase noise cancellation, arXiv preprint

The following presentations relate to open datasets and the various published papers mentioned above: AGU 2023: Multi-Parameter Backus-Gilbert Method: Extracting Parameters from Complex Earth Science Data. Noami Kaplunov, Andreas Fichtner, Coen M Hofstede, Dimitri Zigone and Olaf Eisen; AGU 2023: Fiber-optic airplane seismology. Andreas Fichtner... [Full presentation list continues across pages 8–10]
producing YouTube videos for public outreach
videos produced in last year relate to open datasets relating to this ORD project
livestream of data from the ongoing volcanic eruptions in Iceland (active at least through end of January 2024)

collaborative datasets from the DAS Month project connected us with 24 other universities, and started an ongoing discussion of data handling best practices among that group. We expect to be involved with subsequent discussions and future infrastructure planning.

collaborations with Istanbul Municipality and Bogazici Kandilli Observatory; collaborations with Colorado School of Mines, National Observatory of Athens, optics researchers at 3 different Greek Universities; data shared with Iceland Meteorological Office
group’s expertise with DAS projects has sparked a connection to TotalEnergies, which could bring a significant amount of projects and funding into the department.

community DAS users, and other fiber-optic sensing tools, is rapidly expanding. The number of active academic researchers worldwide is easily at least 1000 people, and standardization of the ORD and FAIR practices will benefit all.

publications.reasoning: The largest count of directly related scientific publications is 8 (from the summary table on page 7), which also provides the most complete list of descriptions. The second source (page 8) adds three further publication descriptions and URLs, but these are new and do not duplicate those in the previous list. All unique descriptions and URLs have been combined, citations are retained where given, and confidence values are propagated or averaged for combined entries.

config.system_prompt:
EXTRACTION STRATEGY:
  1. PRIMARY: Look for data in the specified location/table/section
  2. FALLBACK: If not found, search broader document context for semantically equivalent information
  3. FLEXIBILITY: Allow for format variations, OCR errors, and synonym usage

  LOCATION FLEXIBILITY:
  - Handle table format variations (column/row order, spacing, naming)
  - Consider synonyms and equivalent terms
  - Account for OCR/parsing errors that may affect document quality

  QUALITY STANDARDS:
  - Extract actual values found in the document
  - If uncertain, provide best interpretation with appropriate confidence
  - Only return null if the information category truly doesn't exist
  - Convert abbreviated amounts (k=1000) to full numbers where applicable
  

  REPORT OUTPUT FOCUS:
  - 15 standard output categories in "List of Outputs" table
  - Each category: quantity number, descriptions list, URLs list
  - Separate descriptions from URLs even when mixed in same cell
  - Academic collaborations vs Industrial partnerships (distinct categories)
  - Preserve all detailed descriptions and web addresses
